Hi @kramer65, in this case you need to create your own _CSShake_ animation, and for its purpose you have the `do-shake` mixin. After you clone the repo `git clone https://github.com/elrumordelaluz/csshake.git`, install the basic packages `npm install` (you need [npm installed](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/install) on your system) and you could start trying what you want with the Sass stuff. Try something like ``` scss .shake-horizontal-chunk { @include do-shake('shake-horizontal-chunk', 30, 0, 0, 4s, $chunk: 40%); } ``` in the `csshake.scss` file and then run `npm run build:raw` or `npm run build:min`. Keep in mind that the whole code generated in _CSShake_ is based on `random` generated numbers between the values you use in the `mixin`. For a detailed exmplanation of the mixin, read more [here](https://github.com/elrumordelaluz/csshake#customize) . Cool @OpherV thanks! . thanks @AlphaGit, merged! However I'd appreciate if you have a screenshot or could explain what is the behaviour you had in Edge. Since I an working on OSX I did a simple [pen](http://codepen.io/elrumordelaluz/pen/9c925051ea3ef55c5572e6e5405428a7) to test via [crossbrowsertesting](crossbrowsertesting.com) and didn't see nothing strange, and didn't found any [bug](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/Feedback) related. . lol, sooo funny! thank you for the video @AlphaGit, thanks again for the PR. . Hi @seb0zz don't understand why you need to have the `shake-constant` class as a new shake animation class when it [exists](https://github.com/elrumordelaluz/csshake/blob/master/scss/_tools.scss#L97) yet as a _helper class_. [Here](http://codepen.io/elrumordelaluz/pen/9c925051ea3ef55c5572e6e5405428a7) you have an example to see how it works, just apply the `shake-*` animation constantly. . `shake-constant` should be defined importing the file `csshake.scss` since it imports `_tools.scss` where is defined a variable `$prefix: 'shake' !default;` used in [some lines](https://github.com/elrumordelaluz/csshake/blob/master/scss/_tools.scss#L83-L98) to define the class `.#{$prefix}-constant === .shake-constant` inside each animation created. `shake-constant` does not have an independent behaviour, need to be used as a _modifier_ of a animation created through `do-shake()` mixin. Did you tried `@extend`ing `shake` or another `shake-*` animation? . Right. To have available this class you have to at least _process_ an animation thorugh the mixin. Creating a class `.shake-constant { @include do-shake('shake-constant'); }` will give you the same situation of using `@extend .shake` (but in this case `.shake-constant`) and you'll need to call .shake-constant.shake-constant to have it constantly (like we talked before). Did you tried importing the desired animation from `dist`? Do you have a repo or something with this working? . @seb0zz you could do one of this two things: ``` scss @import "../../../node_modules/csshake/scss/csshake"; .yourClass { @extend .shake.shake-constant; ... } ``` or ``` scss @import "../../../node_modules/csshake/scss/csshake"; %myAnim { @include do-shake(); } .yourClass { @extend %myAnim.shake-constant; ... } ``` . cool! let me know if there's another behavior with css-modules. . @paya-cz thanks for the idea, included [here](https://github.com/elrumordelaluz/csshake/commit/1d111730e0665bddcca42b8cad2c8bd04974527d) . Good catch, thanks! . Should be solved with last changes, thanks! . @greaterweb thanks for the catch, [this](https://github.com/elrumordelaluz/csshake/blob/v1.5.1/scss/_tools.scss#L14-L16) should be correct now! Let me know and thanks again. . @ariunbayar Thanks for the idea. Solved [here](https://github.com/elrumordelaluz/csshake/commit/d73157e1e4d0e677968bfcc28c0839f063f4b75a). . For any reason everything is working for me, but you are absolutely right. Thank you @aboutaaron for the PR! . Hello @madruga88 and thanks for the interest. **CSShake** is based on `random` numbers for its _presets_. You could play around with some numbers in the [reshake](https://github.com/elrumordelaluz/reshake) playground [here](https://elrumordelaluz.github.io/reshake/) but I think you could use the awesome [Bounce.js](http://bouncejs.com/) library to create this kind of _controlled_ animations.. @antivitla I understand what you mean. >Probably your initial target audience was bower-users Not sure if `bower` users but probably most without bundler process -like projects. Could you please provide an example on what `webpack` do or miss about this package? _Bootstrap_ has the `js` files as `main`. I think a good solution could be `"main": "dist/csshake.css"`, in case this work for you (and hopefully for all the `npm` users) absolutely appreciate a PR! Thanks for the catch!. Thanks @antivitla !. @punshonjm thanks for reporting the issue. At the beginning the _shaked_ element needs a `display` property to allow transformations. You are absolutely right that removing/commenting this property prevents this strange behaviour. A simple fix (PR welcome!) could be to switch `display: inline-block` that assume a specific relation with the layout/context into `display: inherits` or test again use cases without `display` property at all. In case you want to contribute with a PR (could be awesome!), should be necessary to test with different kind of html elements because browsers assign a default `display` prop in some elems. In case I found a document with this assumptions will share here. Otherwise, when as soon as I have a peace of time I'll fix this. Thanks again,. Eric, but for now the class name is just .freez. Did you tried `@extend`ing `shake` or another `shake-*` animation? . Right. To have available this class you have to at least _process_ an animation thorugh the mixin. Creating a class `.shake-constant { @include do-shake('shake-constant'); }` will give you the same situation of using `@extend .shake` (but in this case `.shake-constant`) and you'll need to call .shake-constant.shake-constant to have it constantly (like we talked before). Do you have a repo or something with this working? . @seb0zz you could do one of this two things: ``` scss @import "../../../node_modules/csshake/scss/csshake"; .yourClass { @extend .shake.shake-constant; ... } ``` or ``` scss @import "../../../node_modules/csshake/scss/csshake"; %myAnim { @include do-shake(); } .yourClass { @extend %myAnim.shake-constant; ... } ``` . cool! let me know if there's another behavior with css-modules. . @paya-cz thanks for the idea, included [here](https://github.com/elrumordelaluz/csshake/commit/1d111730e0665bddcca42b8cad2c8bd04974527d) . Hello @madruga88 and thanks for the interest. **CSShake** is based on `random` numbers for its _presets_. You could play around with some numbers in the [reshake](https://github.com/elrumordelaluz/reshake) playground [here](https://elrumordelaluz.github.io/reshake/) but I think you could use the awesome [Bounce.js](http://bouncejs.com/) library to create this kind of _controlled_ animations.. @antivitla I understand what you mean. >Probably your initial target audience was bower-users Not sure if `bower` users but probably most without bundler process -like projects. Could you please provide an example on what `webpack` do or miss about this package? _Bootstrap_ has the `js` files as `main`. I think a good solution could be `"main": "dist/csshake.css"`, in case this work for you (and hopefully for all the `npm` users) absolutely appreciate a PR! Thanks for the catch!. Thanks @antivitla !. @punshonjm thanks for reporting the issue. At the beginning the _shaked_ element needs a `display` property to allow transformations. You are absolutely right that removing/commenting this property prevents this strange behaviour. A simple fix (PR welcome!) could be to switch `display: inline-block` that assume a specific relation with the layout/context into `display: inherits` or test again use cases without `display` property at all. In case you want to contribute with a PR (could be awesome!), should be necessary to test with different kind of html elements because browsers assign a default `display` prop in some elems. In case I found a document with this assumptions will share here. Otherwise, when as soon as I have a peace of time I'll fix this. Thanks again,.

. I was having issues specifically with https://github.com/yeoman/generator-gulp-webapp and when I would `gulp wiredep` it wouldn't add the link like it should have. It simply didn't know what files to include.

Now it actually adds the stylesheet and works perfectly. You can test by installing the gulp-webapp generator and starting a new project.

AlphaGit:
@elrumordelaluz Hi! Sorry for the delay. I'm using the latest sass version. The function random is included, but that's not what's actually failing. It somehow fails while performing the multiplication on its result. However, a division goes perfectly fine.
. Hi! Sure, here's a quick comparison:

https://youtu.be/4cJTRG_nLIE

You will see some slight differences but this is the actual test case:

I have an application which on a particular form, on validation error, will add the shake-horizontal class and remove it 300ms later. In Chrome, Safari, and even IE, the form will shake side to side, and later stop.

On Edge the form went NUTS (it was actually pretty funny). It would shake in several directions, increasing the intensity noticeably and then repeating cycles, but certainly not side to side. It would also not stop on its own.

I was working on an old version of the library so I updated and I created my own animation with `do-shake`, but after a while of fighting with the parameters I realized that the problem was with Edge itself. The rest is this PR. :)
. @elrumordelaluz Hi! Sorry for the delay. I'm using the latest sass version. The function random is included, but that's not what's actually failing. It somehow fails while performing the multiplication on its result. However, a division goes perfectly fine.
. Hi! Sure, here's a quick comparison:

https://youtu.be/4cJTRG_nLIE

You will see some slight differences but this is the actual test case:

I have an application which on a particular form, on validation error, will add the shake-horizontal class and remove it 300ms later. In Chrome, Safari, and even IE, the form will shake side to side, and later stop.

On Edge the form went NUTS (it was actually pretty funny). It would shake in several directions, increasing the intensity noticeably and then repeating cycles, but certainly not side to side. It would also not stop on its own.

I was working on an old version of the library so I updated and I created my own animation with `do-shake`, but after a while of fighting with the parameters I realized that the problem was with Edge itself. The rest is this PR. :)
.

antivitla: Yes, it turns out that `"main": "dist/csshake.css"` makes webpack satisfied. And we can use same syntax for importing it in css|stylus|sass. I've tested, seems all good. Made a PR :). Yes, it turns out that `"main": "dist/csshake.css"` makes webpack satisfied. And we can use same syntax for importing it in css|stylus|sass. I've tested, seems all good. Made a PR :).
